entry.title: Combined summary - Electrum security model concerns
entry.summary: In 2012, a series of email conversations took place discussing various issues related to Bitcoin. One of the main topics was the Electrum wallet created by Thomas, specifically its merchant daemon and how it could benefit merchants. However, there were concerns about the security model of Electrum as there was a lack of detailed information on the website. The unauthenticated cleartext JSON protocol between clients and servers was also discussed as a potential risk of using thin clients.The difficulty of communicating transaction confidence to users was acknowledged due to the lack of reported double-spends against unconfirmed transactions. It was suggested that bitcoin.org should have clear explanations and appropriate caution for clients and security models. Gregory Maxwell expressed concern about the lack of description of Electrum's security model but later got in touch with Thomas on IRC to discuss the security issues. As a result, significant parts of Electrum were redesigned to eliminate the issues structurally, representing a massive improvement despite some vulnerabilities.Another topic discussed was finding someone trustworthy and capable to work on the bitcoin.org website. However, some people expressed concerns about the politicization of the matter and the potential for allegations of misconduct. The importance of communication and understanding within the community to avoid conflicts and arrive at mutually beneficial outcomes was highlighted.The conversation also touched on MultiBit Merchant, a Java backend offering a RESTful API using HAL+JSON, which provides a comprehensive set of order and invoice processing, accounting, inventory/delivery management, and customer account handling facilities. There were discussions about the comparison between Electrum and MultiBit in terms of their handling of SPV work.In one conversation, the handling of wallet state in the presence of re-orgs was discussed. Transactions are checked to appear in the blockchain, but it is not clear if the wallet will be in the right state in the case of a chain switch. The conversation then shifts to a comparison between Electrum and MultiBit in terms of their handling of SPV work.There was an attempt to contact someone through IRC but received no response. The discussion continued, and someone expressed their concern that the matter is becoming politicized and may result in allegations of misconduct. However, despite the controversy surrounding the clients page, the group arrived at an agreeable outcome and moved on. The importance of communication and understanding within the community to avoid conflicts and arrive at mutually beneficial outcomes was highlighted.Lastly, the author of one message requested a proper discussion on understanding the bitcoinj security model. A more thorough examination of Electrum's security model was necessary, and it was suggested that a discussion similar to "Understanding the bitcoinj security model" was needed to avoid misunderstandings that result in users taking riskier behaviors.
